trial_identification.studytitle: A study of intranasal remifentanil for intubation and surfactant administration in newborns
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Intranasal remifentanil for pain management during intubation and surfactant administration in premature newborns a randomised double blind controlled pilot study of efficacy

conditions.healthcondition: Pain management for premature infants undergoing intubation.

interventions.interventions: Prior to the intubation surfactant extubation (INSURE) procedure, babies will receive standard care plus intranasal remifentanil 2 micrograms/kg.
interventions.comparator: The comparator treatment is standard care plus intranasal normal saline. Standard care is defined as employing comfort and environmental methods as deemed appropriate by staff. Oral sucrose may be used according to NICU standard protocol.

primaryOutcome.outcome:
The proportion of infants with good or excellent intubating conditions.
Base-line cardiorespiratory and sleep-wake data will be recorded in order to calculate the immediate post-procedural Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) score. Real-time physiological data will be downloaded from monitors for later analysis. These include: blood pressure obtained using an arterial transducer or a non-invasive blood pressure module; heart rate obtained from an electrocardiogram lead attached to cardiogram/respiratory monitor; and oxygen saturation obtained from an oxygen saturation monitor.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 and 3 minutes after intubation. Real-time physiological data will be downloaded from monitors for later analysis.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Pain assessed using the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) score
Number of intubation attempts and total duration (limit of 3 attempts OR 20 seconds each attempt OR intubation associated with desaturations and bradycardia).
Adverse events including episodes of bradycardia and number of neonates requiring intervention (volume expanders or inotropes) for hypotension
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: The first hour after study drug administration
The first hour after study drug administration

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Neonatal outcome at discharge from NICU (satisfactory weight gain, equivalent to term corrected, breathing on own without respiratory support, can suck and feed without the need of assistance eg. gastric tube feeding, can maintain body temperature).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Born at John Hunter Childrens Hospital and transferred to Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. Require the INSURE procedure as part of their medical care. Are 2844 weeks post-conceptional age at the time of the procedure.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Need for urgent intubation for resuscitation. Major congenital anomalies likely to influence reliability of the primary outcome measure. Severe neurological obtundation. Current clinical seizures. Concomitant muscle relaxant.

trial_design.concealment: The person determining if a subject is eligible for inclusion in the trial is unaware to which group the subject will be allocated. Allocation is concealed by central randomisation by computer.
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation will be achieved by a prepared randomisation schedule using a computerised random-number generator, stratified by corrected gestational age (<32 weeks, >32 weeks).

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Kaleidoscope Neonatal Intensive Care Unit John Hunter Children's Hospital Lookout Road New Lambton NSW 2310

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Anaesthesia, Intensive Care & Pain Management John Hunter Children's Hospital Lookout Road New Lambton NSW 2310

othercollaborator.othercollaboratoraddress: Hunter Medical Research Institute John Hunter Hospital Lookout Road New Lambton NSW 2310

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of intranasal remifentanil for improving intubating conditions in neonates requiring the INSURE procedure as part of their medical care. Usual pain management (comfort/environmental measures and age/weight-appropriate sucrose) will be provided to all neonates.
